course_title: Moral and Ethical Foundations of Social Work

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate an understanding of how ethical theory applies to social work practice;
Demonstrate an ability to identify and critically appraise personal value positions that may be reflected in social work assessments;
Demonstrate knowledge of ethical responsibilities as outlined in the AASW Code of Ethics;
Demonstrate an awareness of cultural considerations and their implications for ethical decision making in social work practice;
Demonstrate a capacity to develop, articulate and defend ethical positions and decisions in a professional context;
Demonstrate an ability to critically analyse and use ethical decision-making frameworks and processes;
Demonstrate a capacity to articulate ethical understanding and positions with clarity and insight;

Develop interprofessional practice skills including role clarification, team functioning, interprofessional communication and client-centred care. N.B.: This learning objective relates to the IPCP module only.

assessments.task_description:
An Inspera-based quiz covering course content from Weeks 1-4 will be made available from 9:00am on 25 August until 11:00am on 26 August.

  • The quiz will consist of 30 multiple-choice questions.
  • Students are required to install the UQ Inspera secure browser on their device before taking the quiz.
  • The quiz is open-book.
  • Students will have 45 minutes to complete the quiz once it has commenced.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.due_date: Please refer to the HABS1240 Learn.UQ course site for due date information.
assessments.task_description:
The IPCP is a HMBS Faculty project. It is not marked or co-ordinated by John.

This is a team assessment and all team members are expected to contribute equally to the teamâ€™s assessment items. Teams will be assigned during your first tutorial. There are three (3) parts to this assessment:

Part 1: This part requires you to complete a worksheet and will draw on the online and face-to-face content from Module 1 of the IPCP curriculum focusing on role-clarification and client-centred care.

Length: There is no word limit for the worksheet.

Part 2: This part involves creating a 3-minute video which draws upon the online and face-to-face content from Modules 2 and 3 of the IPCP curriculum focusing on interprofessional communication, team functioning and client-centred care.

Length: Video 3 minutes

Part 3: This part involves a written assignment (300 words max) which draws on the online and face-to-face content from Modules 2 and 3 of the IPCP curriculum focusing on how client-centred care can be improved.

Length: The word limit for the written assignment is 300 words combined, including in-text references

Teams will need to submit all three parts of your assessment in the Assessment tab on the IPCP Learn.UQ course site. Additional information regarding submission and assessment information can be found on the IPCP Learn.UQ course site.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This assessment is an online submission via Blackboard. Please refer to the HABS1240 Learn.UQ course site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
An Inspera-based quiz covering course content from Weeks 1-9 will be made available from 3:00pm on 7 October until 5:00pm on 8 October.

  • The quiz will consist of 30 multiple-choice questions.
  • Students are required to install the UQ Inspera secure browser on their device before taking the quiz.
  • The quiz is open-book.
  • Students will have 45 minutes to complete the quiz once it has commenced.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.assessment_title: Practice dilemma. Designing an ethical response
assessments.task_description:
This is a group task, evaluated through a combination of group and individual marks, in which students will submit a filmed response to an ethical practice dilemma.

For full details available, please refer to the course Blackboard site.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This assessment requires students to submit an electronic version of their assignment via Blackboard. The electronic version of your assignment will be submitted via Blackboard, using the Turnitin software.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Cannibalism and other lifestyle choices

In which the course is introduced, base behaviour is discussed and the hope of a brighter future is not entirely extinguished.

Read Banks (2021), Chapter 1.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L06, L07

learning_activities.topic:
Rights

Alice asked the Cheshire Cat, "Who was sitting in a tree, What road do I take?" The cat asked, "Where do you want to go?" "I don't know", Alice answered. Then, said the cat, "It really doesn't matter, does it?"

Read more koan-like observations in Banks (2021), Chapter 5.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Rights Alice asked the Cheshire Cat, "Who was sitting in a tree, What road do I take?" The cat asked, "Where do you want to go?" "I don't know", Alice answered. Then, said the cat, "It really doesn't matter, does it?" Read more koan-like observations in Banks (2021), Chapter 5 .
